question: 2 (g)
sols_html:
We draw where our function is increasing, decreasing, concave up, concave down as well as the only local extrema we found on a graph. We also include the asymptotes.

Then we draw.
sols_raw:
We draw where our function is increasing, decreasing, concave up, concave down as well as the only local extrema we found on a graph. We also include the asymptotes.

[[File:M104 Dec2013 Q2g1.jpg|300px]]


Then we draw.

[[File:M104 Dec2013 Q2g2.jpg|300px]]
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{x^{2}}{x^{2} - 4}.\end{aligned}\]

Its first and second derivatives are given by

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = -\frac{8x}{(x^{2} - 4)^{2}}, \quad f''(x) = \frac{8(3x^{2} + 4)}{(x^{2} - 4)^{3}}\end{aligned}\]

g) Draw the graph of f(x). Accurately place all critical points and inflection points, indicate all asymptotes, and make sure your graph correctly shows where f(x) is increasing and decreasing and correctly shows its concavity.
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>
f(x) = \frac{x^{2}}{x^{2} - 4}.
</math>
Its first and second derivatives are given by
:<math>
f'(x) = -\frac{8x}{(x^{2} - 4)^{2}}, \quad f''(x) = \frac{8(3x^{2} + 4)}{(x^{2} - 4)^{3}}
</math>

<b>g)</b>
Draw the graph of <i>f(x)</i>. Accurately place all critical points and
inflection points, indicate all asymptotes, and make sure your graph correctly shows
where <i>f(x)</i> is increasing and decreasing and correctly shows its concavity.
